comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Tried to write this on the blog but was rejected three times. The State Library NSW has several prints of this image - one of them is dated "Approx.1917" - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=190057# . And . . . there is another 'half' to this photo (also dated "c.1917") showing the stern of the 'Star', the west side of the new wharf, and an unidentified liner - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=190056# I wonder if State Records have this other photo in their collection in a better condition and resolution, so that the liner's name can be read. I have a hunch that this ship could be the RMS Niagara ( en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RMS_Niagara ) which was an early visitor to the new wharf in July 1913 ( trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/15439011 ). Just a hunch!

comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] I think it might be the number of links in your comment, you wouldn't be rejected for anything else :D

I'll try and put your comment over on the blog. Very interesting note about the other 'half' of this photo - we'll dig around and see if we can find something...

AB

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/state-records-nsw] Ha! Too many links spoil the blog! Thanks for posting that for me. Trying to find a comparison stern view of the Niagara . . .

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I am fairly sure the ship in the companion photo is the 'Niagara' when the stern is compared with this photo at full zoom - goo.gl/IX1b . The ship, at the time named "The Titanic of the Pacific" and on her maiden voyage, had enough history for a couple of movies. It makes sense that a Maritime Services Board (Sydney Harbour Trust?) photographer would take a photo of the new wharf with a new large ship alongside. So imho the July 1913 date is accurate. And the 'Star' is not really the star of this show!
